This dark blue, walking mushroom is covered in purple and green protrusions and darkens the area with its very presence.

This ambulatory fungus is a relative of myconids and often found in their colonies. The presence of duskwilts is considered a favorable thing, as their ability to absorb light gives myconids a tactical advantage against surface dwellers.

entries.name: Defensive Fungi
entries: As part of a myconid colony, the duskwilt provides a first line of defense. They are sent in against creatures with light sources to impede their vision and progress, moving close enough to absorb light attack intruders at range. If intruders persist and close with the duskwilts, they release their spores and fight hand to hand until reinforcements arrive.

entries.name: Companions to Ghouls
entries: Like the {@creature deathcap myconid|ToB|deathcap myconids}, duskwilts sometimes ally with {@creature ghoul||ghouls} and the {@creature darakhul|ToB}. A duskwilt may be assigned to a particular troop or patrol, bolstering the ghouls with their spores.

trait.name: Central Stalk Weakness
entries: The mulcher's central stalk lies hidden within the mulcher's fungal mass. When exposed, the central stalk can be attacked and destroyed (AC 13; hp 50; vulnerability to acid, cold, and fire damage). If the central stalk is destroyed, the mulcher has disadvantage on attack rolls and can't use Expose Stalk until it regrows a new central stalk at the end of its next long rest.

trait.name: Disturbed Soil (Exposed Stalk Only)
entries: The ground within 20 feet of the mulcher is difficult terrain.

trait.name: Mulcher Pit
entries: If the mulcher burrows at least 20 feet straight toward a creature, it can dig a 10-foot diameter, 20-foot-deep pit beneath the creature. Each Large or smaller creature in the pit's area must succeed on a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw or fall into the mycelium-lined pit and land {@condition prone}, taking 14 ({@damage 4d6}) piercing damage from the spiked mycelium in addition to any falling damage. The mulcher can make one Mycelium Spike attack against a {@condition prone} creature in the pit as a bonus action.

trait.name: Stalk Regeneration (Exposed Stalk Only)
entries: The mulcher gains 15 hp at the start of its turn if it has at least 1 hp.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The mulcher makes two Mycelium Spike attacks.

action.name: Mycelium Spike
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 2d10 + 4}) piercing damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 15} Strength saving throw or be {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 15}) if the mulcher doesn't have two other creatures {@condition grappled}.

action.name: Excavate
entries: While underground, the mulcher creates a 20-foot square cover on the ground over itself and lurks just below the surface. The cover is identical to the ground around it. When a creature enters the cover's space, the mulcher can make one Mycelium Spike attack against the creature as a reaction, destroying the cover. The target has disadvantage on the saving throw to avoid being {@condition grappled}.

bonus.name: Expose Stalk
entries: The mulcher exposes its central stalk above the ground until the end of its next turn or until it ends the effect as a bonus action. While the central stalk is exposed, the mulcher can't burrow.

bonus.name: Rapid Burrow
entries: The mulcher burrows up to 60 feet. {@action Opportunity attack||Opportunity attacks} against it are made with disadvantage when the mulcher burrows out of an enemy's reach in this way. Creatures {@condition grappled} by it are freed before it burrows.

reaction.name: Emergent Stalk
entries: When the mulcher is reduced to below half its hp maximum or when a creature scores a critical hit against it, the mulcher immediately uses Expose Stalk.
The large orange flower reveals a tall, blue stalk. The petals clamp on a swarm of insects, showing their fleshy, tooth-like nature.
A voracious fungus, the mulcher hides within topsoil, waiting to trap oblivious creatures.

entries.name: Hidden Danger
entries: This massive fungus is as sweeping and bulky as a {@creature dragon turtle}. It uses the ground as cover, where it can ambush prey that travels above it. Alternatively, it can trigger pit traps beneath its prey, impaling the falling creatures on its spike-like mycelium. Once prey has been impaled, the fungus drinks in the victim's blood as greedily as groundwater.

entries.name: Weak Spot
entries: When injured or when it fails to capture sufficient food, the mulcher pushes its fragile central stalk to the surface, releasing insect-attracting pheromones to gain some quick nutrients from the meager prey.

monster.name: Mush Marcher
languages: understands Common, plus one language known by its grower, but can't speak

trait.name: Partial Echolocation
entries: The mush marcher's {@sense blindsight} is reduced to 10 feet while {@condition deafened}.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The mush marcher makes two Spore-Laced Claw attacks or one Mycelial Harpoon attack and one Spore-Laced Claw attack.

action.name: Mycelial Harpoon
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 15/30 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 2d6 + 3}) piercing damage, and the harpoon sticks in the target if it is a Medium or smaller creature. While the harpoon is stuck, the target takes 7 ({@damage 2d6}) piercing damage at the start of each of its turns, the mush marcher can't make Mycelial Harpoon attacks against other targets, and the target and mush marcher can't move further than 30 feet away from each other. A creature, including the target, can take its action to detach the harpoon by succeeding on a {@dc 13} Strength check. Alternatively, the mycelial thread connecting the mush marcher to the harpoon can be attacked and destroyed (AC 12; hp 10; vulnerability to thunder damage; immunity to bludgeoning, poison, and psychic damage), dislodging the harpoon into an unoccupied space within 5 feet of the target and preventing the mush marcher from using Recall Harpoon.

action.name: Spore-Laced Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d4 + 3}) piercing damage plus 9 ({@damage 2d8}) poison damage.

action.name: Slowing Spores {@recharge 5}
entries: The mush marcher releases spores from its cap. Each creature within 20 feet of the mush marcher must make a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw. On a failure, a creature takes 18 ({@damage 4d8}) poison damage and is {@condition poisoned}. On a success, a creature takes half the damage and isn't {@condition poisoned}. While {@condition poisoned} in this way, a creature's speed is halved. A {@condition poisoned} creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

bonus.name: Recall Harpoon
entries: The mush marcher pulls on the mycelial threads connecting it to its harpoon, returning the harpoon to its empty hand. If the harpoon is stuck in a creature, that creature must succeed on a {@dc 13} Strength saving throw or be pulled up to 15 feet toward the mush marcher.
A hulking red and white mushroom stomps forward. As it patrols, the gills beneath its cap taste the air for any sign of movement.

When a ritual is performed on a patch of moondrop agaricus on the night of a full moon, the fruiting bodies of these rare mushrooms begin a slow transformation. By the next full moon, between one and three of these mushrooms sprout to a great size, uprooting themselves with three thick legs and patrolling the nearby area, awaiting orders.

entries.name: Loyal Minions
entries: Mush marchers are friendly and loyal to their grower, following their orders almost instinctively. If its grower is especially neglectful or cruel, a mush marcher abandons them, setting out to find a new purpose in life, becoming hostile to its grower only as a last resort. While obscure, the ritual to create mush marchers overlaps many disciplines, and {@class druid||druids}, alchemists, and {@class wizard||wizards} might stumble across the ritual needed to create them. Thus, mush marchers can be found in druidic groves, wizard towers, priestly caverns, or hidden laboratories in cities and villages.

monster.name: Void Fungus
languages: understands Common and Void Speech but can't speak

trait.name: False Appearance
entries: While the Void fungus remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from a patch of glowing fungus.

trait.name: Illumination
entries: The Void fungus sheds dim light in a 10-foot radius.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Void fungus makes two Poisonous Mycelium or Psychic Blast attacks. If the Void fungus hits one creature with both Psychic Blast attacks, the target must succeed on a {@dc 13} Charisma saving throw or be {@condition charmed} for 1 minute. The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

action.name: Poisonous Mycelium
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d8 + 2}) piercing damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) poison damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} until the end of its next turn.

action.name: Psychic Blast
entries: {@atk rs} {@hit 5} to hit, range 60 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d8 + 3}) psychic damage.

action.name: Consume Energy
entries: The hair-like tendrils dangling from the Void fungus's cap briefly flash as it draws psychic energy from a creature it can see within 30 feet of it. The target must make a {@dc 13} Charisma saving throw, taking 18 ({@damage 4d8}) psychic damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. The fungus regains hp equal to the damage dealt.
A purple glow emanates from the translucent caps of a lavender fungus with pale strands dangling from it. The largest batch of the fungus moves, its dark mycelium reaching up beckoningly.

Void fungus is a semi-sentient cluster of phosphorescent mushrooms that psychically assault living creatures. Once their prey is helpless, they feast on their vital fluids through a fibrous mycelium network.

entries.name: Mobile Fungus
entries: Once a cluster of void fungus has been fed ample blood, one or more swollen mushrooms undergo a metamorphosis, breaking apart from the rest as a creature with enhanced power and mobility. These ambulatory Void fungi collect prey for the colony.

entries.name: Alien Origins
entries: Originating from some long-forgotten corner of the Void, the Void fungus resembles a sinister, otherworldly version of the pixie's parasol mushroom. How their spores spread across the planes is a subject of esoteric debate. This eldritch fungus has been known to turn up in the nightmares of spellcasters, usually alongside even greater threats.

trait.name: Keen Hearing and Smell
entries: The garmvvolf has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on hearing or smell.

trait.name: Multiple Heads
entries: The garmvvolf has three heads. While it has more than one head, the garmvvolf has advantage on saving throws against being {@condition blinded}, {@condition charmed}, {@condition deafened}, {@condition frightened}, {@condition stunned}, and knocked {@condition unconscious}. Whenever the garmvvolf takes 25 or more damage in a single turn, one of its heads dies. If all its heads die, the garmvvolf dies.

At the end of its turn, the garmvvolf grows two heads for each of its heads that died since its last turn, unless it has taken fire damage since its last turn. The garmvvolf regains 10 hp for each head regrown in this way.

trait.name: Trampling Charge
entries: If the garmvvolf moves at least 20 feet straight toward a creature and then hits it with a Bite attack on the same turn, that target must succeed on a {@dc 16} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}. If the target is {@condition prone}, the garmvvolf can make one Bite attack against it as a bonus action.

trait.name: Wakeful
entries: While the garmvvolf sleeps, at least one of its heads is awake.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The garmvvolf makes as many Bite attacks as it has heads.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d6 + 5}) piercing damage plus 10 ({@damage 3d6}) poison damage.

action.name: Tripartite Howl {@recharge 5}
entries: The garmvvolf's heads exhale a three-part howl, one filled with poisonous spittle, one a thunderous bellow, and one a frightful bay, in a 30-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 16} Dexterity saving throw. On a failure, a creature takes 17 ({@damage 5d6}) poison damage and 17 ({@damage 5d6}) thunder damage and becomes {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. On a success, a creature takes half the damage and isn't {@condition frightened}. A {@condition frightened} creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

trait.name: Amorphous
entries: The gearmass can move through a space as narrow as 1 foot wide without squeezing.

trait.name: Clanging Mass
entries: The gearmass is filled with metal objects that clang, scrape, and clink together as it moves. When it moves, it has disadvantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks to stay silent until the start of its next turn.

trait.name: Ooze Nature
entries: The gearmass doesn't require sleep.

trait.name: Rust Metal
entries: Any nonmagical weapon made of metal that hits the gearmass corrodes. After dealing damage, the weapon takes a permanent and cumulative -1 penalty to damage rolls. If its penalty drops to -5, the weapon is destroyed. Nonmagical ammunition made of metal that hits the gearmass is destroyed after dealing damage.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The gearmass makes two Gear Slam or Cog Toss attacks. If it hits one creature with both Gear Slam attacks, the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 14}), and the gearmass uses Engulf on the target.

action.name: Gear Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 10 ft., one creature. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d8 + 3}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Cog Toss
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 20/60 ft., one creature. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d8 + 3}) bludgeoning damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 14} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Engulf
entries: The gearmass engulfs a Medium or smaller creature {@condition grappled} by it. The engulfed target is {@condition blinded}, {@condition restrained}, and unable to breathe, and it must succeed on a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw at the start of each of the gearmass's turns or take 14 ({@damage 4d6}) acid damage.

Any nonmagical ferrous metal armor, weapons, or other items the target is wearing corrode at the start of each of the gearmass's turns. If an object is either metal armor or a metal shield being worn or carried, it takes a permanent and cumulative -1 penalty to the AC it offers. Armor reduced to an AC of 10 or a shield that drops to a +0 bonus is destroyed. If an object is a metal weapon, it rusts as described in the Rust Metal trait.
If the gearmass moves, the engulfed target moves with it. The gearmass can have only one creature engulfed at a time.

trait.name: Charge
entries: If the ghost knight templar is mounted and moves at least 20 feet straight toward a creature and then hits it with a shadow blade attack on the same turn, the target takes an extra 10 ({@damage 3d6}) slashing damage.

trait.name: Incorporeal Movement
entries: The ghost knight templar can move through other creatures and objects as if they were difficult terrain. It takes 5 ({@damage 1d10}) force damage if it ends its turn inside an object.

trait.name: Turning Defiance
entries: The ghost knight templar and any undead within 30 feet of it have advantage on saving throws against effects that turn undead.

trait.name: Undead Nature
entries: The ghost knight templar doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The ghost knight templar makes three Shadow Blade attacks.

action.name: Shadow Blade
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 1d8 + 5}) slashing damage plus 10 ({@damage 3d6}) necrotic damage.

action.name: Stride of Damnation {@recharge 5}
entries: The ghost knight templar moves up to its speed through its enemies. This movement doesn't provoke {@action opportunity attack||opportunity attacks}. Each creature through which the templar passes must make a {@dc 16} Dexterity saving throw, taking 35 ({@damage 10d6}) cold damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. The templar can't use this action while mounted.

bonus.name: Ghostly Mount
entries: The ghost knight templar can summon or dismiss a {@creature ghostly mount|ToB3}, mounting or dismounting it as part of this bonus action without spending movement. The mount uses the statistics of a {@creature warhorse skeleton}, except it has the Incorporeal Movement trait, a flying speed of 60 feet, 40 hit points, and resistance to cold and necrotic damage and bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage from nonmagical attacks. If the mount is slain, it disappears, leaving behind no physical form, and the templar must wait 1 hour before summoning the mount again.

items.name: Incorporeal Movement
entries: The mount can move through other creatures and objects as if they were difficult terrain. It takes 5 ({@damage 1d10}) force damage if it ends its turn inside an object.

trait.name: Blood Sense
entries: The giant flea can pinpoint, by scent, the location of creatures that have blood within 60 feet of it.

trait.name: Keen Smell
entries: The giant flea has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on smell.

trait.name: Standing Leap
entries: The giant flea's long jump is up to 30 feet and its high jump is up to 15 feet, with or without a running start.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) piercing damage, and the flea attaches to the target. While attached, the flea doesn't attack. Instead, at the start of each of the flea's turns, the target loses 4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) hp due to blood loss. The flea can detach itself by spending 5 feet of movement. It does so after draining 12 hp of blood from the target or the target dies. A creature, including the target, can take its action to detach the flea by succeeding on a {@dc 11} Strength check.

bonus.name: Leaping Escape
entries: The giant flea leaps up to 15 feet without provoking {@action opportunity attack||opportunity attacks}.

trait.name: Blood Sense
entries: The giant flea can pinpoint, by scent, the location of creatures that have blood within 60 feet of it.

trait.name: Keen Smell
entries: The swarm has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on smell.

trait.name: Ravenous
entries: When a creature that doesn't have all of its hp starts its turn in the swarm's space, that creature must succeed on a {@dc 12} Dexterity saving throw or lose 5 ({@damage 2d4}) hp from blood loss.

trait.name: Standing Leap
entries: The swarm's long jump is up to 30 feet and its high jump is up to 15 feet, with or without a running start.

trait.name: Swarm
entries: The swarm can occupy another creature's space and vice versa, and the swarm can move through any opening large enough for a Tiny flea. The swarm can't regain hp or gain temporary hp.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 0 ft., one creature in the swarm's space. {@h}14 ({@damage 4d6}) piercing damage, or 7 ({@damage 2d6}) piercing damage if the swarm has half its hp or fewer.

trait.name: Fluorescing Challenge
entries: The giant mantis shrimp has advantage on Charisma ({@skill Intimidation}) checks while agitated, as its natural fluorescence flashes in a disorienting array.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The giant mantis shrimp makes two Sonic Claw attacks.

action.name: Sonic Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) piercing damage. The target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 14}) if it is a Medium or smaller creature and the giant mantis shrimp doesn't have another creature {@condition grappled}. Whether or not the attack hits, the target must succeed on a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw or take 5 ({@damage 1d10}) thunder damage and be {@condition deafened} and {@condition stunned} until the end of its next turn.

bonus.name: Water Jet
entries: Each creature within 5 feet of the shrimp must succeed on a {@dc 14} Dexterity saving throw or be {@condition blinded} until the start of its next turn. The shrimp then swims up to half its swimming speed without provoking {@action opportunity attack||opportunity attacks}.

variant.name: Siege Mantis Shrimp
entries: Some giant mantis shrimp wield claws that resemble clubs more than spears. These mantis shrimp are especially devastating to terrain and structures, and are sometimes enchanted to serve deep ones or {@creature sahuagin}. A siege mantis shrimp gains the following additional trait:

entries.name: Siege Monster
entries: The mantis shrimp deals double damage to objects and structures.
In addition, the giant mantis shrimp has the following action option in place of Multiattack and Sonic Claw:

entries.name: Sonic Smash
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}18 ({@damage 4d6 + 4}) bludgeoning damage. In addition, either nonmagical armor or a nonmagical shield worn or carried by the target (the shrimp's choice) is partly destroyed and takes a permanent and cumulative −1 penalty to the AC it offers. Armor reduced to an AC of 10 or a shield that drops to a +0 bonus is destroyed. Whether or not the attack hits, the target and any creature within 5 feet of it, other than the shrimp, must succeed on a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw or take 11 ({@damage 2d10}) thunder damage and be {@condition deafened} and {@condition stunned} until the end of its next turn.

action.name: Sonic Smash
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}18 ({@damage 4d6 + 4}) bludgeoning damage. In addition, either nonmagical armor or a nonmagical shield worn or carried by the target (the shrimp's choice) is partly destroyed and takes a permanent and cumulative −1 penalty to the AC it offers. Armor reduced to an AC of 10 or a shield that drops to a +0 bonus is destroyed. Whether or not the attack hits, the target and any creature within 5 feet of it, other than the shrimp, must succeed on a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw or take 11 ({@damage 2d10}) thunder damage and be {@condition deafened} and {@condition stunned} until the end of its next turn.

items.name: Siege Monster
entries: The mantis shrimp deals double damage to objects and structures.

trait.name: Beast of Burden
entries: The giant mole lizard is considered to be a Huge Beast for the purpose of determining its carrying capacity.

trait.name: Sunlight Sensitivity
entries: While in sunlight, the lizard has disadvantage on attack rolls, as well as on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The lizard makes two Claw attacks. It can replace one attack with a use of Constricting Tail.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) slashing damage.

action.name: Constricting Tail
entries: A Large or smaller creature within 5 feet of the lizard must succeed on a {@dc 12} Dexterity saving throw or be {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 14}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}, can't breathe, and begins to suffocate, and the giant mole lizard can't use Constricting Tail on another target.

bonus.name: Mass Shove
entries: Each Large or smaller creature within 10 feet of the giant mole lizard and that isn't {@condition grappled} by it must succeed on a {@dc 14} Strength saving throw or be pushed up to 15 feet away from the lizard and knocked {@condition prone}.

trait.name: Spiny Body
entries: A creature that touches the giant pufferfish or hits it with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it takes 2 ({@damage 1d4}) piercing damage. While the pufferfish is puffed up, this damage increases to 5 ({@damage 2d4}).

trait.name: Water Breathing
entries: The giant pufferfish can breathe only underwater.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 2d8 + 3}) piercing damage, or 12 ({@damage 2d8 + 3}) piercing damage while puffed up.

action.name: Spine
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d4 + 3}) piercing damage, or 8 ({@damage 2d4 + 3}) piercing damage while puffed up. The target must make a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw, taking 5 ({@damage 2d4}) poison damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. If the target fails the saving throw by 5 or more, it takes 2 ({@damage 1d4}) poison damage at the end of its next turn.

bonus.name: Burst of Speed {@recharge 5}
entries: The giant pufferfish takes the {@action Dash} action.

bonus.name: Puff Up (Recharges after a Short or Long Rest)
entries: For 1 minute, the giant pufferfish increases in size by filling its stomach with air or water. While puffed up, the pufferfish is Medium, doubles its damage dice on Bite and Spine attacks (included in the attacks), and makes Strength checks and Strength saving throws with advantage. If the pufferfish lacks the room to become Medium, it attains the maximum size possible in the space available.

trait.name: False Appearance
entries: While the giant walking stick remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from normal forest vegetation, such as a small tree or a large branch.

trait.name: Forest Camouflage
entries: The giant walking stick has advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks made to hide in forested terrain.

trait.name: Trampling Charge
entries: If the giant walking stick moves at least 20 feet straight toward a creature and then hits it with a Ram attack on the same turn, that target must succeed on a {@dc 13} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}. If the target is {@condition prone}, the walking stick can make one Spine attack against it as a bonus action.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The giant walking stick makes two Spine attacks or one Ram attack and one Spine attack.

action.name: Ram
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 2d10 + 3}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Spine
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) piercing damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) poison damage.

action.name: Deadfall {@recharge 5}
entries: If the giant walking stick is at least 15 feet off the ground, it can fall to the ground, landing on its feet in a space it can see within 20 feet of it that contains one or more other creatures. Each of those creatures must make a {@dc 13} Dexterity saving throw. On a failure, a creature takes 21 ({@damage 6d6}) bludgeoning damage and is knocked {@condition prone}. On a success, a creature takes half the damage, isn't knocked {@condition prone}, and is pushed 5 feet out of the walking stick's space into an unoccupied space of the creature's choice. In addition, each creature within 10 feet of the walking stick when it lands must succeed on a {@dc 13} Dexterity saving throw or take 10 ({@damage 3d6}) bludgeoning damage and be knocked {@condition prone}.

bonus.name: Startling Display
entries: Each creature within 5 feet of the walking stick must succeed on a {@dc 13} Intelligence saving throw or be {@condition incapacitated} until the end of its next turn. The walking stick then flies up to its flying speed without provoking {@action opportunity attack||opportunity attacks}.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The firestorm giant makes two Obsidian Axe or Firestorm Bolt attacks.

action.name: Obsidian Axe
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}19 ({@damage 3d8 + 6}) slashing damage plus 3 ({@damage 1d6}) cold damage and 3 ({@damage 1d6}) fire damage.

action.name: Firestorm Bolt
entries: {@atk rs} {@hit 6} to hit, range 120 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 3d6 + 3}) fire damage plus 10 ({@damage 3d6}) cold damage.

action.name: Lava Geyser {@recharge 5}
entries: The firestorm giant gestures at a point on the ground it can see within 60 feet of it. A fountain of molten rock erupts from that point in a 10-foot-radius, 40-foot-high cylinder. The area is difficult terrain for 1 minute. Each creature in the cylinder must make a {@dc 16} Dexterity saving throw. On a failure, a creature takes 24 ({@damage 7d6}) fire damage and is coated in hardened lava. On a success, a creature takes half the damage and isn't coated in hardened lava. A creature coated in hardened lava has its speed halved while it remains coated. A creature, including the coated creature, can take its action to break and remove the hardened lava, ending the effect.
The huge giant with a wedge-shaped head snarls and extends a hand. A geyser of molten lava bursts out from the ground as the gesture ends.

Firestorm giants originated with the rare offspring of a {@creature frost giant} and a {@creature fire giant}. Now their own people, firestorm giants maintain their distance from both sides of their heritage, living and celebrating their own unique culture.

entries.name: Quake Walkers
entries: Firestorm giants dwell in cold and arctic climates, and they instinctively follow fault lines and glacial valleys as their clans migrate. Occasionally, a clan settles near a volcano or large hot spring.

entries.name: Natural Protectors
entries: The fire and ice swirling through firestorm giants' veins war constantly within them, and they find solace in the rhythmic chaos of the natural world, particularly geologically active areas. Because of this, they viciously protect nature from destruction and despoilment. They harbor a deep hatred of magical winters, poisonous mine waters, dam construction, and other disruptions to nature.

entries.name: Unexpected Hospitality
entries: Firestorm giants understand the dangers of their arctic and volcanic homes and are often sympathetic to outsiders braving such dangers. Their sympathy and hospitality last only so long as the outsiders don't cause magical or unnatural disruptions to the giants' homes.

entries.name: Firestorm Giants in Midgard
entries: Firestorm giants dwell on the frozen glaciers of the Northlands where their migrations follow subterranean ley lines. Most of the clans view the God of the North Wind as a perversion of the natural order, actively working against Boreas and his frost giant clans. A few follow Loki as a figure of conjoined frost and flame, rather different than the human view.

trait.name: Death Malison
entries: When the hellfire giant dies, the runes on its body flash a bright green then turn to mundane malachite. Each creature within 20 feet of the giant must succeed on a {@dc 16} Constitution saving throw or be cursed for 7 days or until it is lifted by a {@spell remove curse} spell or similar magic. While cursed, the creature has disadvantage on saving throws and on the first attack roll it makes on each of its turns. Fiends have disadvantage on the saving throw.

trait.name: Rune-Powered Weapons
entries: The hellfire giant's weapon attacks are magical. When the giant hits with any weapon, the weapon deals an extra {@damage 2d8} fire damage (included in the attack).

trait.name: Stone Camouflage
entries: The giant has advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks made to hide in rocky terrain.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The giant makes two Greatclub or Runic Blast attacks.

action.name: Greatclub
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}19 ({@damage 3d8 + 6}) bludgeoning damage plus 9 ({@damage 2d8}) fire damage.

action.name: Runic Blast
entries: {@atk rs} {@hit 7} to hit, range 60 ft., one target. {@h}25 ({@damage 4d10 + 3}) force damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 16} Constitution saving throw or its speed is halved until the end of its next turn. Fiends have disadvantage on the saving throw.

action.name: Invisibility Rune
entries: The hellfire giant magically turns {@condition invisible} until it attacks, or until its concentration ends (as if concentrating on a spell). Any equipment the giant wears or carries is {@condition invisible} with it.

reaction.name: Runic Shield
entries: The hellfire giant adds 4 to its AC against one attack that would hit it as green runes encircle the giant. To do so, the giant must see the attacker and can't be {@condition invisible}.
Clad in a golden breastplate, a stone-skinned giant holds a ball of crackling green eldritch energy in the palm of its hand.

Hellfire giants were once {@creature stone giant||stone giants} who were enslaved by fiends. These powerful soldiers eventually rose against their masters and escaped their hellish prison. Hellfire giants now take brutal reprisals against anyone they deem allies to fiends.

entries.name: Rune Powered
entries: To empower their giant slaves, fiends etched malachite runes into the stony skin of the giants. Though these runes gave the giants new power, it also marked them with a hellish taint. Hellfire giants often take great pleasure in using their runic powers against fiends.

entries.name: Vengeful Hunters
entries: Feeling removed from their stone giant brethren, many hellfire giants have become wanderers who pursue lives as bounty hunters. However, even the most dedicated bounty hunting hellfire giant will abandon or delay its bounties if it believes it can strike at fiends.

entries.name: Fiendish Bloodline
entries: Much to the dismay of the first hellfire giants, the hellish traits and runes pass along to the giants' offspring. Seeing their power as a curse, many of the surviving giants choose not to have children, while others teach their children the importance of utilizing the fell power for the good of giantkind. Most hellfire giants have mixed opinions on {@race tiefling||tieflings}. Some despise them, viewing them as the fell children of their former masters, while others feel a kinship with the {@race tiefling||tieflings}. After all, like the giants, they were altered against their will by the machinations of fiends.

trait.name: Limited Amphibiousness
entries: The lantern giant can breathe air and water, but it needs to be submerged at least once every 4 hours to avoid {@quickref suffocating||2}.

trait.name: Hypnotic Luminescence
entries: The tendril on the lantern giant's head sheds bright light in a 60-foot radius and dim light for an additional 60 feet. When a creature that can see the light starts its turn within 60 feet of the giant, the creature must succeed on a {@dc 18} Charisma saving throw or become {@condition charmed} for 24 hours, regarding the giant as a friendly acquaintance. If the giant or one of its allies harms the {@condition charmed} creature, this effect ends. If the creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the giant's Hypnotic Luminescence for the next 24 hours. At the start of its turn, the lantern giant chooses whether this light is active.

trait.name: Speak with Aquatic Creatures
entries: The lantern giant can communicate with Beasts and Monstrosities that have a swimming speed as if they shared a language.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The lantern giant makes three Trident attacks. It can replace one attack with a use of Spellcasting.

action.name: Trident
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 12} to hit, reach 10 ft. or range 20/60 ft. one target. {@h}18 ({@damage 3d6 + 8}) piercing damage, or 21 ({@damage 3d8 + 8}) piercing damage if used with two hands to make a melee attack.

action.name: Crush of the Deep {@recharge 5}
entries: The lantern giant subverts the environment to summon the pressure of the deepest ocean depths in a 40-foot cube of water centered on a point it can see within 120 feet of it. Each creature in the cube must make a {@dc 17} Constitution saving throw as the pressure increases, taking 44 ({@damage 8d10}) bludgeoning damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The lantern giant casts one of the following spells, requiring no material components and using Charisma as the spellcasting ability (spell save {@dc 15}):

entries: A ghostly bobbing light illuminates a towering figure clad in the weathered ruins of a sunken ship's rigging.

Lantern giants are massive bipedal humanoids with rust-red skin that walk along the bottom-most depths of the ocean floor. A tendril hangs from the giant's forehead, tipped by a nodule that glows with a ghostly light.

entries.name: Helpful Hermits
entries: Lantern giants are one of the few creatures intimately familiar with the deepest reaches of the sea, and they are willing to act as guides or scouts to travelers.

entries.name: Treasure Seekers
entries: Few lantern giants remain, but each patrols the darkest depths of the ocean floor, searching ruins and wrecks for something to bolster their dying kingdom. Lantern giants are incredibly secretive, never revealing what they are seeking. Still, they are more than happy to align themselves with travelers eager to plumb the ocean depths—as long as the travelers don't ask too many questions.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The giant makes three Pitchfork attacks, or it makes one Pitchfork attack then uses Grab and Throw. Alternatively, it can make one pitchfork attack then use Grab and Throw.

action.name: Pitchfork
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}20 ({@damage 3d10 + 4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Rock
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 7} to hit, range 60/240 ft. {@h}20 ({@damage 3d10 + 4}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Grab
entries: The shire giant reaches out and grabs a Medium or smaller creature it can see within 10 feet of it. The target must succeed on a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw or be {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 15}) by the giant. Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}.

action.name: Throw
entries: The shire giant throws a creature it is grappling at a space it can see within 30 feet of it. The thrown creature takes 14 ({@damage 4d6}) bludgeoning damage and must succeed on a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw or land {@condition prone}. If the target space is occupied by another creature, that creature must succeed on a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw or take 14 ({@damage 4d6}) bludgeoning damage and be knocked {@condition prone}.
This hill giant wears a massive, home-spun tunic and hefts a pitchfork as large as itself. It is less bulky but visibly healthier than its nomadic kin.

Long ago, shire giants were hill giants who settled into a rough, agricultural lifestyle. Now, they assemble sprawling barn-houses, till fields of crops, and keep livestock in small family units on large farmsteads. While more settled than their nomadic cousins, they are no less dangerous. A shire giant's conceptions of "livestock" and "property" are expansive to creatures smaller than themselves, and their punishment for trespassing is almost universally death and consumption.

entries.name: Aggressive Agriculturalists
entries: Shire giants require an enormous amount of food to feed them and their kin, and they tend to be indiscriminate about what, exactly, they farm. Fields of tubers or wheat abut wastelands of basically-edible weeds, while sheep share pastures with {@creature mammoth||mammoths}, sauropods, or wooly {@creature rhinoceros||rhinoceroses}. Even intelligent creatures aren't immune to the shire giants' will, as the giants occasionally declare a village part of their livestock, extracting regular tribute in treasure, goods, or food. These tributes aren't always one-sided, and many shire giant farmsteads send these villages surplus goods or goods they can't use or don't want. Shire giants will trade with outsiders, offering wool, lumber, and monster-guts they no longer need for worked goods they can't make on their own, but they prefer to get such goods via trade with or tribute from villages in their territory when possible.

entries.name: Territorial
entries: Shire giants are fiercely protective of their sprawling farms. Fenceposts, stacks of rocks, and the corpses of previous trespassers—often marked with runes promising death to trespassers—mark the boundaries of their territory. Monsters, bandits, and even lesser giants are treated as glorified guard dogs, set to controlling the giants' livestock and killing lesser intruders. More dangerous, or more brazen, trespassers may draw the giants' personal attention.

entries.name: Straightforward Brawlers
entries: In combat, shire giants are straightforward combatants. They lumber into battle, impaling smaller opponents with their pitchforks while grabbing and flinging tougher foes away from themselves or into their allies. They order any monsters or subordinates into the fight ahead of them, allowing the giants to remain relatively safe in combat. Shire giants rarely fight to the death; retreating to their homestead, or finding a new home entirely, is greatly preferable to death.

trait.name: Forged Forgery
entries: Thursir armorers wear armor that has been forged from dwarven armor and shaped to resemble dwarven armor. Skilled blacksmiths can recognize and exploit this design quirk. When a creature proficient with smith's tools scores a critical hit against the thursir armorer, the armorer's armor breaks, reducing the armorer's Armor Class by 5 until the thursir armorer repairs the armor. If the thursir armorer is critically hit by any creature while its armor is broken, its armor shatters and is destroyed, reducing the armorer's Armor Class to 12.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The thursir armorer uses Flinging Smash, if available. It then makes two Battleaxe attacks or one Battleaxe attack and one Shield Bash attack.

action.name: Battleaxe
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 2d8 + 5}) slashing damage, or 16 ({@damage 2d10 + 5}) slashing damage if used with two hands.

action.name: Shield Bash
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 2d4 + 5}) bludgeoning damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 16} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Flinging Smash {@recharge 5}
entries: The armorer makes a sweeping strike with its shield. Each creature within 10 feet of the armorer must succeed on a {@dc 16} Strength saving throw or be pushed up to 15 feet away from the armorer and knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Runic Armor (3/Day)
entries: The armorer can inscribe the thurs rune on its armor. When a creature hits the armorer with a melee weapon attack while the rune is active, the creature takes 4 ({@damage 1d8}) lightning damage and can't take reactions until the start of its next turn. The rune lasts for 1 minute.

bonus.name: Harness Dwarven Soul
entries: The thursir armorer draws on the soul fragment trapped in one of the dwarven skulls on its belt. The armorer has advantage on ability checks when using smith's tools and on attack rolls using a battleaxe, handaxe, light hammer, or warhammer until the start of its next turn. The armorer carries six skulls on its belt.

The red-bearded giant wears mismatched metal plates, and it wields a massive battle axe in one hand and a shield in the other. Both match the style of the armor, with various metal plates smelted together. Dwarven skulls carved with runes decorate the giant's belt.

entries.name: Dwarven Hatred
entries: The {@creature thursir giant|ToB|thursir giants'} animosity toward dwarves comes from an ancestral rivalry in the blacksmithing arts. The thursir go out of their way to bring misery to any dwarves in their path. Armorers accomplish this by forging their armor and weapons from those of dwarven warriors they slay.

entries.name: Soul Collectors
entries: Armorers keep the skulls of their greatest dwarven kills on their belts, displayed to intimidate dwarves and to brag to other thursir. The skulls are inscribed with a thursir rune that keeps a portion of the fallen dwarf's soul connected, giving the giant access to a measure of the dwarf's knowledge.

entries.name: Honored Smiths
entries: Armorers are renowned within {@creature thursir giant|ToB} enclaves for the quality of their craftsmanship. Obsessed with repurposing dwarven equipment in a way that is effective yet still clearly dwarven, armorers never become leaders of their communities, as their focus on their work blinds them to the ambitions and happenings of their communities.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The priestess has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: The priestess's weapon attacks are magical.

trait.name: Protect the Hearth
entries: When the priestess is hit by a weapon attack, up to two friendly creatures within 60 feet of her that can see her can use their reactions to move up to their speed toward the hearth priestess.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The hearth priestess uses Hearth Blessing, then makes two Runic Staff attacks.

action.name: Runic Staff
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 2d6 + 3}) bludgeoning damage and 4 ({@damage 1d8}) fire damage.

action.name: Hearth Blessing
entries: The hearth priestess calls upon her deity and connection with the hearth to enhance her allies. The priestess empowers one friendly creature she can see within 30 feet of her with one of the following options until the start of her next turn.

items.name: Hearth's Burn.
items.entry: The target's weapon ignites, and when the target hits with the weapon, the weapon deals an extra 3 ({@damage 1d6}) fire damage.

items.name: Hearth's Comfort.
items.entry: If the target is {@condition charmed} or {@condition frightened}, the condition immediately ends. In addition, the target gains 5 ({@damage 1d10}) temporary hp.

items.name: Hearth's Protection.
items.entry: The target's Armor Class increases by 2, and its armor is immune to spells and effects that target or affect the armor, such as the {@spell heat metal} spell or a {@creature rust monster||rust monster's} antennae.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The hearth priestess casts one of the following spells, using Wisdom as the spellcasting ability (spell save {@dc 13}):

entries: The giant woman with braided red hair wears vestments made of polar bear and mammoth pelts and wields a metal staff etched with glowing runes. As she chants, the runes on the staff flare brighter.

Though {@creature thursir giant|ToB|thursir giants} often treat the females of their enclaves as lower than males, spellcasting, a trait found almost exclusively in their women, is held in high regard. Such spellcasters are respected, and they often act in an advisory role to an enclave's chieftain.

entries.name: Messengers of the Gods
entries: Male thursir giants believe their own actions determine outcomes, not prayers to any god, but hearth priestesses know better. These giant women perform rituals and prayers to gods on behalf of their clans, ensuring the future of the clan.

entries.name: Hearth and Forge Magic
entries: Hearth priestesses worship gods of the forge and war, and use their magic to enhance the weaponry and smithing of their male counterparts. Despite the disrespect thursir males feel about thursir females, no warrior goes into battle without the blessing of the clan's hearth priestess.

trait.name: Telescoping Eyes
entries: The gigantura has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight, and magical darkness doesn't impede the gigantura's {@sense darkvision}. In addition, it has disadvantage on ability checks and saving throws against being {@condition blinded}.

trait.name: Water Breathing
entries: The gigantura can breathe only underwater.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The gigantura uses Horrific Gaze. It then makes one Bite attack and two Tail Slap attacks.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}25 ({@damage 3d12 + 6}) piercing damage. If the target is a Huge or smaller creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 18} Dexterity saving throw or be swallowed by the gigantura. A swallowed creature is {@condition blinded} and {@condition restrained}, it has total cover against attacks and other effects outside the gigantura, and it takes 21 ({@damage 6d6}) acid damage at the start of each of the gigantura's turns. The gigantura can have up to two Huge, four Large, six Medium, or eight Small creatures swallowed at one time.

If the gigantura takes 30 damage or more on a single turn from a creature inside it, the gigantura must succeed on a {@dc 20} Constitution saving throw at the end of that turn or regurgitate all swallowed creatures, which fall {@condition prone} in a space within 10 feet of the gigantura. If the gigantura dies, a swallowed creature is no longer {@condition restrained} by it and can escape from the corpse by using 20 feet of movement, exiting {@condition prone}.

action.name: Tail Slap
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}17 ({@damage 2d10 + 6}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Horrific Gaze
entries: The gigantura's telescoping eyes swirl disconcertingly in the direction of one creature it can see within 60 feet of it. If the target can see the gigantura, the target must succeed on a {@dc 18} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition stunned} until the end of its next turn. A target that successfully saves is immune to this gigantura's Horrific Gaze for the next 24 hours.

trait.name: Acidic Coating
entries: A creature that touches the glacial crawler or hits it with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it takes 9 ({@damage 2d8}) acid damage.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The glacial crawler can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Snow Camouflage
entries: The glacial crawler has advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks made to hide in snowy terrain.

trait.name: Tunneler
entries: The glacial crawler can burrow through ice, snow, and permafrost, and leaves a 5-foot-diameter tunnel in its wake.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The glacial crawler makes two Bite attacks and one Tail Spike attack, or it makes three Superheated Acid Spit attacks.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 10 ft., one creature. {@h}16 ({@damage 2d10 + 5}) piercing damage plus 9 ({@damage 2d8}) acid damage.

action.name: Tail Spike
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 9} to hit, reach 10 ft., one creature. {@h}19 ({@damage 4d6 + 5}) piercing damage. The target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 17}) if it is a Large or smaller creature and the crawler doesn't have another creature {@condition grappled}.

action.name: Superheated Acid Spit
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 7} to hit, range 60 ft., one creature. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d8 + 3}) acid damage plus 9 ({@damage 2d8}) fire damage.

action.name: Acidic Spray {@recharge 5}
entries: The glacial crawler spews superheated digestive juices in a 30-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 17} Dexterity saving throw. On a failure, a creature takes 18 ({@damage 4d8}) acid and 18 ({@damage 4d8}) fire damage and is coated in heated acid. On a success, a creature takes half the damage and isn't coated in acid. A creature coated in heated acid takes 4 ({@damage 1d8}) acid damage and 4 ({@damage 1d8}) fire damage at the start of each of its turns. A creature, including the coated target, can take its action to wash or scrub off the acid, ending the effect.

trait.name: Aura of Hope
entries: The gnyan is surrounded by an aura of uplifting courage. Each friendly creature within 30 feet of the gnyan has advantage on saving throws against being {@condition frightened}.

trait.name: Glorious Milk
entries: A gnyan can spend 1 minute slowly drinking from a bowl of melted ice water. When it stops, the bowl is filled with a pale milk. A creature that drinks the milk regains 7 ({@damage 2d6}) hit points, and its {@condition exhaustion} level is reduced by up to two levels. After a gnyan's milk has restored a total of 20 hit points or reduced a total of four {@condition exhaustion} levels in creatures, the gnyan can't create milk in this way again until it finishes a long rest.

trait.name: Pounce
entries: If the gnyan moves at least 20 feet straight toward a creature and then hits it with a Claw attack on the same turn, that target must succeed on a {@dc 13} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}. If the target is {@condition prone}, the gnyan can make one Bite attack against it as a bonus action.

trait.name: Snow Camouflage
entries: The gnyan has advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks made to hide in snowy terrain.

trait.name: Snow Strider
entries: The gnyan can move across icy surfaces without needing to make an ability check, and difficult terrain composed of ice or snow doesn't cost it extra movement. In addition, it leaves no tracks or other traces of its passage when moving through snowy terrain.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The gnyan makes one Bite attack and one Claw attack.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) piercing damage plus 3 ({@damage 1d6}) cold damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 2d4 + 4}) slashing damage plus 3 ({@damage 1d6}) cold damage.

action.name: Avalanche's Roar {@recharge 6}
entries: The gnyan looses a terrible blasting roar of ice and snow in a 30-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 13} Dexterity saving throw. On a failure, a creature takes 21 ({@damage 6d6}) cold damage and is {@condition restrained} until the end of its next turn as frost and snow coats its limbs. On a success, a creature takes half as much damage and isn't {@condition restrained}.

bonus.name: Snow Step
entries: The gnyan teleports, along with any equipment it is wearing or carrying, up to 30 feet to an unoccupied space it can see. The origin and destination spaces must contain snow.

monster.name: Goblin Siege Engine

immune.note: from nonmagical attacks not made with adamantine weapons

languages: understands the languages of its creator but can't speak

trait.name: Adaptable Locomotion
entries: Moving through difficult terrain doesn't cost the siege engine extra movement. In addition, it has advantage on ability checks and saving throws made to escape a grapple or end the {@condition restrained} condition.

trait.name: Construct Nature
entries: The siege engine doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

trait.name: Defensive Mount
entries: The siege engine can serve as a mount for one Large creature, up to four Medium creatures, or up to six Small or smaller creatures. While mounted, creatures riding in the siege engine's turret gain half cover.

trait.name: Immutable Form
entries: The siege engine is immune to any spell or effect that would alter its form.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The siege engine has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Siege Monster
entries: The siege engine deals double damage to objects and structures.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The siege engine makes three Slam attacks.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}22 ({@damage 3d10 + 6}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Acid Jet {@recharge 5}
entries: The siege engine sprays a jet of acid in a 30-foot line that is 5 feet wide. Each creature in that line must make a {@dc 17} Dexterity saving throw, taking 40 ({@damage 9d8}) acid damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

trait.name: Construct Nature
entries: The godslayer doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

trait.name: Divine Sense
entries: The godslayer can pinpoint the location of Celestials, Fiends, divine avatars, and deities within 120 feet of it and can sense the general direction of such creatures within 1 mile of it. This sense extends into the Ethereal and Shadow Planes.

trait.name: Divine Slayer
entries: The godslayer's attacks affect immortal beings, such as gods. Celestials, Fiends, divine avatars, and deities don't have resistance to the damage from the godslayer's attacks. If such a creature would normally have immunity to the damage from the godslayer's attacks, it has resistance instead. If the godslayer reduces a Celestial, Fiend, divine avatar, or deity to 0 hp, it absorbs the target's divine energy, preventing the target from reviving or being resurrected until the godslayer is destroyed.

trait.name: Immutable Form
entries: The godslayer is immune to any spell or effect that would alter its form.

trait.name: Inscrutable
entries: The godslayer is immune to any effect that would sense its emotions or read its thoughts, as well as any divination spell that it refuses. Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) checks made to ascertain the godslayer's intentions or sincerity have disadvantage.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If the godslayer fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The godslayer has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Siege Monster
entries: The godslayer deals double damage to objects and structures.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The godslayer uses Arcane Lexicon. It then makes three Energy Glaive or Rune Discus attacks.

action.name: Energy Glaive
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 19} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}48 ({@damage 7d10 + 10}) force damage.

action.name: Rune Discus
entries: {@atk rs} {@hit 19} to hit, range 80/320 ft., one target. {@h}41 ({@damage 7d8 + 10}) force damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 25} Wisdom saving throw or spells and magical effects are suppressed on the target and the target can't cast spells for 1 minute. The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

action.name: Arcane Lexicon
entries: Glyphs on the godslayer's body cast ghostly copies into the air, forming into eldritch incantations. The godslayer chooses up to three creatures it can see within 90 feet of it, choosing one of the following options for each target. A creature can't be targeted by more than one effect at a time, and the godslayer can't use the same option on more than one target.

items.name: Death Glyph.
items.entry: The target must succeed on a {@dc 25} Wisdom saving throw or be marked for death until the start of the godslayer's next turn. While marked for death, the target takes an extra 11 ({@damage 2d10}) force damage each time the godslayer hits the target with an Energy Glaive attack.

items.name: Glyph of Despair.
items.entry: The target must succeed on a {@dc 25} Charisma saving throw or be overwhelmed with despair for 1 minute. While overwhelmed with despair, the target has disadvantage on ability checks and attack rolls.

items.name: Glyph of Pain.
items.entry: The target must succeed on a {@dc 25} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition incapacitated} until the end of its next turn as it is overwhelmed by pain. This glyph has no effect on Undead or Constructs.

items.name: Glyph of Summoning.
items.entry: The target must succeed on a {@dc 25} Wisdom saving throw or be magically teleported to an unoccupied space within 15 feet of the godslayer.

items.name: Retributive Glyph.
items.entry: The target must succeed on a {@dc 25} Dexterity saving throw or be marked with a retributive glyph until the end of its next turn. While marked, the creature takes 9 ({@damage 2d8}) force damage each time it hits a creature with a weapon attack.

items.name: Stupefying Glyph.
items.entry: The target must succeed on a {@dc 25} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition blinded} and {@condition deafened} until the end of its next turn.

bonus.name: Hunting Step
entries: The godslayer magically teleports, along with any equipment it is wearing or carrying, up to 120 feet to an unoccupied space within 15 feet of a Celestial, Fiend, divine avatar, or deity it senses with Divine Sense, magically shifting from the Material Plane to the Ethereal or Shadow Planes or vice versa. The godslayer has advantage on the next attack roll it makes against the target before the start of its next turn. Glowing glyphs appear at the origin and destination when it uses this bonus action.

reaction.name: Parry Spell
entries: If the godslayer succeeds on a saving throw against a spell of 8th level or lower that targets only the godslayer, the spell has no effect. If the godslayer succeeds on the saving throw by 5 or more, the spell is reflected back at the spellcaster, using the slot level, spell save DC, attack bonus, and spellcasting ability of the caster.

legendary.name: Arcane Word
entries: The godslayer uses one glyph from its Arcane Lexicon on a target it can see within 90 feet of it.

legendary.name: Attack
entries: The godslayer makes one Energy Glaive or Rune Discus attack.

legendary.name: Move
entries: The godslayer moves up to its speed without provoking {@action opportunity attack||opportunity attacks}.

legendary.name: Rejuvenating Repair (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The godslayer regains 65 ({@damage 10d12}) hp.

immune.note: from nonmagical attacks not made with adamantine weapons

trait.name: Construct Nature
entries: The chain golem doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

trait.name: Immutable Form
entries: The chain golem is immune to any spell or effect that would alter its form.

trait.name: Infernal Tetanus
entries: A creature infected with this disease manifests symptoms {@dice 2d4} days after infection, which include fever, headache, sore throat, and muscle aches. This disease affects the nervous system, causing painful, debilitating muscle spasms that eventually inhibit mobility, speech, and breathing. Until the disease is cured, at the end of each long rest, the infected creature must make a {@dc 16} Constitution saving throw. On a failure, the creature's Dexterity score is reduced by {@dice 1d4} and it is {@condition paralyzed} for 24 hours. This reduction lasts until the creature finishes a long rest after the disease is cured. If the disease reduces the creature's Dexterity to 0, the creature dies. On a successful save, the infected creature instead suffers one level of {@condition exhaustion}, and, until the disease is cured or the {@condition exhaustion} is removed, it must succeed on a {@dc 16} Constitution saving throw to cast a spell with a verbal component. A creature that succeeds on three saving throws recovers from the disease.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The chain golem has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: The chain golem's attacks are magical.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The chain golem makes two Chain attacks.

action.name: Chain
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}18 ({@damage 4d6 + 4}) slashing damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 16} Constitution saving throw or contract the infernal tetanus disease (see the Infernal Tetanus trait). The target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 14}) if it is a Large or smaller creature and the golem doesn't have another creature {@condition grappled}.

action.name: Imprison
entries: The chain golem creates a prison of chains around a Medium or smaller creature {@condition grappled} by it. While imprisoned, the creature is {@condition restrained} and takes 14 ({@damage 4d6}) piercing damage at the start of each of its turns. The imprisoned creature or a creature within 5 feet of the golem can take an action to free the imprisoned creature. Doing so requires a successful {@dc 16} Strength check, and the creature making the attempt takes 7 ({@damage 2d6}) piercing damage.
A mass of tangled, rusty chains rattles its barbed links. As it rises and moves, it takes on a vaguely humanoid form, like a figure draped in a hooded cloak made of chains.

Chain golems are native to infernal regions and created by {@creature chain devil||chain devils}. The creation process involves several {@creature chain devil||chain devils} participating in a ritual, each devil shedding one or more chains from its body and giving a sliver of its life force. The mass of chains can then be commanded by any chain devil involved in its creation.

entries.name: Infernal Hunters
entries: Chain golems are created by {@creature chain devil||chain devils} to hunt down particular quarry and returning the creature to its infernal creators. The quarry may be an escaped soul, a creature that betrayed the devils, or an enemy in retreat. Once set on the trail, a chain golem pursues relentlessly until it catches the creature or is destroyed.

entries.name: Servile
entries: If the {@creature chain devil||chain devils} that created the golem die, the golem attempts to seek out others. If one or more {@creature chain devil||chain devils} reenact the ritual that initially created the golem, adding a chain from their own bodies to the golem, it becomes theirs to command.

immune.note: from nonmagical attacks not made with adamantine weapons

trait.name: Construct Nature
entries: The ice golem doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

trait.name: Ice Cavity
entries: The ice golem's torso is a block of ice that it can liquefy and refreeze, trapping and preserving creatures inside it. If the golem takes 15 fire damage or more on a single turn, the cavity liquefies if it was frozen.
When the cavity is frozen, a creature that touches the golem or hits it with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it takes 9 ({@damage 2d8}) cold damage.

When the cavity is liquefied, a creature within 5 feet of the golem can take an action to pull a {@condition petrified} creature out of the golem, if the golem has one inside it. Doing so requires a successful {@dc 16} Strength check, and the creature making the attempt takes 9 ({@damage 2d8}) cold damage.

trait.name: Immutable Form
entries: The ice golem is immune to any spell or effect that would alter its form.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The ice golem has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The ice golem makes two Slam attacks, or it makes one Slam attack and uses Preserve Creature.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 3d6 + 5}) bludgeoning damage plus 9 ({@damage 2d8}) cold damage. The target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 16}) if it is a Medium or smaller creature and the golem doesn't have another creature {@condition grappled}.

action.name: Preserve Creature
entries: The ice golem preserves a Medium or smaller creature {@condition grappled} by it. The preserved creature can't breathe and is {@condition restrained} as it starts to freeze. The {@condition restrained} creature must make a {@dc 16} Constitution saving throw at the end of its next turn. On a failure, it takes 18 ({@damage 4d8}) cold damage, becomes {@condition petrified} in ice in the golem's Ice Cavity, and has total cover from attacks and other effects outside the golem. If this damage reduces a creature to 0 hp, the creature automatically becomes stable. A {@condition petrified} creature removed from the golem's Ice Cavity thaws, ending the petrification, in {@dice 1d4} rounds or immediately after taking fire damage. On a success, the creature takes half the damage and is ejected, landing {@condition prone} in an unoccupied space within 5 feet of the golem. If the golem moves, the preserved creature moves with it. The golem can have only one creature preserved at a time. The golem can't use Preserve Creature if its Ice Cavity is frozen.

reaction.name: Freeze or Liquefy Cavity
entries: The ice golem freezes or liquefies its Ice Cavity.
This barrel-chested humanoid has metal straps leading from its shoulders to legs made from the same metal. The metal in its torso holds a block of ice in place.
Created to incapacitate and capture creatures on behalf of its controller, an ice golem follows the target assigned to it until it captures its quarry and returns its controller.

entries.name: Icy Hunters
entries: Ice golems operate best in cold climates or during winter. While their creation allows them to withstand some heat, they can't carry out their tasks effectively in constant temperatures above 100 degrees Fahrenheit.

entries.name: Rogue Golems
entries: Uncontrolled ice golems continue following their main directive, but they focus on capturing whenever they have an empty chest cavity. These golems kidnap their victims and deposit their captives relatively unharmed in a location they have declared as their home bases. Fortunately, the golems have no concept of concealing their movement, making them and their targets easy to track.

monster.name: Origami Golem

immune.note: from nonmagical attacks not made with adamantine weapons

languages: understands the languages of its creator but can't speak

trait.name: Construct Nature
entries: The origami golem doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

trait.name: False Appearance (Unfolded Form Only)
entries: While the golem remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from an ordinary paper screen, tapestry, or similar flat paper or fabric artwork.

trait.name: Immutable Form
entries: The golem is immune to any spell or effect that would alter its form, except Fold.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The golem has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: The golem's weapon attacks are magical.

trait.name: Standing Leap (Frog Form Only)
entries: The golem's long jump is up to 30 feet and its high jump is up to 15 feet, with or without a running start.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The origami golem makes three Lacerating Strike or Wing Buffet attacks.

action.name: Lacerating Strike
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 3d8 + 3}) slashing damage.

action.name: Wing Buffet (Dragon or Swan Form Only)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 3d6 + 3}) bludgeoning damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 15} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Hazardous Hop (Frog Form Only)
entries: If the golem jumps at least 15 feet as part of its movement, it can then use this action to land on its feet in an unoccupied space it can see. Each creature within 10 of the golem when it lands must make a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw. On a failure, a creature takes 33 ({@damage 6d10}) bludgeoning damage and is knocked {@condition prone}. On a success, it takes half the damage and isn't knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Shredded Breath (Dragon Form Only) {@recharge 5}
entries: The golem exhales a spray of paper fragments in a 30-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw. On a failure, a creature takes 31 ({@damage 9d6}) slashing damage and is {@condition blinded} until the end of its next turn. On a success, a creature takes half the damage and isn't {@condition blinded}.

action.name: Trumpeting Blast (Swan Form Only) {@recharge 5}
entries: The golem emits a trumpeting blast in a 30-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw. On a failure, a creature takes 31 ({@damage 7d8}) thunder damage and is {@condition deafened} until the end of its next turn. On a success, a creature takes half the damage and isn't {@condition deafened}.

bonus.name: Fold
entries: The golem can fold and reshape its papery body to resemble a Large dragon, a Large swan, or a Medium frog. It can use this bonus action again to unfold into a Large, flat piece of decorative fabric or paper. Its statistics, other than its size, are the same in each form. It reverts to its unfolded form if it dies.
A vellum tapestry tears away from its wall mounts, then folds itself into the form of a paper dragon the size of a horse.

Origami golems are exquisitely crafted from fine textiles, such as paper, vellum, papyrus, or starched silks. Origami golems serve well as hidden sentries, appearing as expensive, but innocuous screens, wall hangings, artwork, or floor-coverings until they attack.

entries.name: Murderous Masterworks
entries: Some creators have a more sinister role in mind for the origami golem. These creatures use the golems as assassins, sneaking the creatures into areas where the intended victim will be, or delivering it as a gift. The golems then attack when opportunity allows.

monster.name: Tar Golem

immune.note: from nonmagical attacks not made with adamantine weapons

languages: understands the languages of its creator but can't speak

trait.name: Construct Nature
entries: The tar golem doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

trait.name: Fire Hazard
entries: When the tar golem takes fire damage, it bursts into flame. The golem continues burning until it takes cold damage, is immersed in water, or it uses Quench. A creature that touches the burning golem or hits it with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it takes 5 ({@damage 1d10}) fire damage. While burning, the golem's weapon attacks deal an extra 5 ({@damage 1d10}) fire damage on a hit.

trait.name: Hardened Tar
entries: If the tar golem takes cold damage in the same round it is reduced to 0 hp, it is {@condition paralyzed} for 1 minute, remaining alive. If it takes fire damage while {@condition paralyzed}, it regains a number of hp equal to the fire damage dealt. Otherwise, it dies when the condition ends.

trait.name: Immutable Form
entries: The tar golem is immune to any spell or effect that would alter its form.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The tar golem has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: The tar golem's weapon attacks are magical.

trait.name: Noxious Smoke (Burning Only)
entries: While the tar golem is burning, it gives off poisonous fumes. A creature that starts its turn within 5 feet of the burning golem must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} as long as it remains within 5 feet of the golem and for 1 round after it leaves the area.

trait.name: Spider Climb
entries: The tar golem can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without having to make an ability check.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The tar golem makes three Slam attacks.

action.name: Slam.
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) bludgeoning damage.

bonus.name: Draw Flames
entries: The tar golem can extinguish up to a 10-foot cube of nonmagical fire within 5 feet of it, drawing the fire into itself and activating its Fire Hazard trait.

bonus.name: Quench (Burning Only)
entries: The tar golem extinguishes any fire on it, deactivating its Fire Hazard trait.
Hot, steaming tar rises from a barrel into a roughly humanoid shape with a menacing posture.

There are two basic types of tar golems. The first is made from wood tar, rendered from the wood and roots of pine trees, while the second is made from naturally occurring asphalt, as that found in tar pits or rendered from coal. Other than the source of the tar, both types of golems are identical, with some creators preferring the more floral scent of the wood tar.

entries.name: Seaside Constructs
entries: Tar golems are typically found aboard ships or on docks, where tar used in waterproofing ships is plentiful. In combat situations, a tar golem can be a surprise defense against boarders and can help stop the spread of fire. Military ships and well-to-do pirates often catapult the golems onto enemy ships to wreak havoc in advance of boarding parties.

entries.name: Creature of Utility
entries: While a tar golem is of great use in battle, on most ships it has a role in day-to-day life. The golem can waterproof sails and seal planks on the deck or in the hull. A ship's doctor may use a golem to apply tar to a wound to prevent infection or to kill a fungal infection. Its magical nature allows a golem to replenish itself over time, provided it isn't used excessively for such duties.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The bilge gremlin can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Aura of Mechanical Mishap
entries: The bilge gremlin's presence interferes with nonmagical objects that have moving parts, such as clocks, crossbows, or hinges, within 20 feet of it. Such objects that aren't being worn or carried malfunction while within the aura, and, if in the aura for more than 1 minute, they cease to function until repaired. If a creature in the aura uses a nonmagical object with moving parts, roll a {@dice d6}. On a 5 or 6, weapons such as crossbows or firearms misfire and jam, and other objects cease to function. A creature can take its action to restore the malfunctioning object by succeeding on a {@dc 13} Intelligence check.

trait.name: Filth Dweller
entries: The bilge gremlin is immune to disease.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d4 + 3}) piercing damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or contract the sewer plague disease.

action.name: Makeshift Weapon
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 20/60 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) bludgeoning, piercing, or slashing damage.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The bilge gremlin can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Aura of Mechanical Mishap
entries: The bilge gremlin's presence interferes with nonmagical objects that have moving parts, such as clocks, crossbows, or hinges, within 20 feet of it. Such objects that aren't being worn or carried malfunction while within the aura, and, if in the aura for more than 1 minute, they cease to function until repaired. If a creature in the aura uses a nonmagical object with moving parts, roll a {@dice d6}. On a 4, 5, or 6, weapons such as crossbows or firearms misfire and jam, and other objects cease to function. A creature can take its action to restore the malfunctioning object by succeeding on a {@dc 13} Intelligence check.

trait.name: Filth Dweller
entries: The bilge gremlin is immune to disease.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The bilge gremlin bosun makes one Bite attack and two Makeshift Weapon attacks.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d4 + 4}) piercing damage plus 5 ({@damage 2d4}) poison damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or contract the sewer plague disease.

action.name: Makeshift Weapon
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 20/60 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) bludgeoning, piercing, or slashing damage.

trait.name: Aura of Drunkenness
entries: The story keeper radiates an aura of drunkenness to a radius of 20 feet. Each creature that starts its turn in the aura must succeed on a {@dc 12} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} for 1 hour. A creature that has consumed alcohol within the past hour has disadvantage on the saving throw.
